title: 107_hr2252
content: The Act titled "Conduit Contribution Prevention Act of 2001" increases penalties for violations of conduit contribution ban. The Act "Conduit Contribution Prevention Act of 2001" increases civil money penalties and criminal penalties for knowing and willful violations of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. Civil penalties are increased to not less than 300 percent of the amount involved in the violation and not more than the greater of $50,000 or 1000 percent of the amount involved. The Act "Conduit Contribution Prevention Act of 2001" increases criminal penalties for violations of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. The fine for knowingly and willfully committing a violation involving $1,000 or more is not less than 300 percent of the amount involved and not more than $50,000 or 1000 percent of the amount involved. The Act "Conduit Contribution Prevention Act of 2001" increases penalties for violations of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. Violators of section 320 involving $1,000 or more may face a fine of not less than 300 percent of the amount involved, up to $50,000 or 1000 percent of the violation amount. The United States Sentencing Commission will establish guidelines for these penalties. The United States Sentencing Commission will establish guidelines for penalties for violations of section 320 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971, taking into account variations in the contribution amount. The Commission will also submit an explanation of any guidelines promulgated or amended to Congress. The United States Sentencing Commission will establish guidelines for penalties for violations of section 320 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971, considering variations in contribution amounts. The Commission must promulgate the guideline within 90 days of the enactment of the Act, following the procedures outlined in the Sentencing Reform Act of 1987. The Commission will establish guidelines for penalties for violations of section 320 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 within 90 days of the Act's enactment. Amendments are made to ensure compliance with the procedures outlined in the Sentencing Reform Act of 1987. Amendments to the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 include mandatory referral to the Attorney General for violations of section 320 and an extension of the statute of limitations to 5 years for such violations. These amendments apply to violations occurring after the enactment of the Act. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to extend the ban on foreign contributions to all campaign-related disbursements, including those to political committees and for independent expenditures. The amendments apply to disbursements made after the enactment of the Act.
